# OpenWeedLocator Welcome to the OpenWeedLocator (OWL) project, an opensource hardware and software weed detector that uses entirely off-the-shelf componentry, very simple green-detection algorithms (with capacity to upgrade to in-crop detection) and 3D printable parts.

#Text=OWL integrates weed detection on a Raspberry Pi with a relay control board or custom driver board, in a custom designed case so you can attach any 12V solenoid, relay, lightbulb or  device for low-cost, simple and open-source site-specific weed control.
#Text=Projects to date have seen OWL mounted on robots, vehicles and bicycles for spot spraying.

#Text=For the latest ideas and news, check out the \[Discussion\](https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator/discussions) tab.  ### News \*\*08-05-2024\*\* - Check out the latest Compact OWL enclosures!

#Text=\[bike\_owl\_cropped\](https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator/assets/51358498/17ad4ead-429e-4384-9e74-b050a536897f)        \|  ### Official Publications  #### OpenWeedLocator (OWL): An open-source, low-cost device for fallow weed detection  This is the original OWL publication, released in \[Scientific Reports (open access)\](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-021-03858-9).

#Text=A range of green detection algorithms were tested including ExG (excess green 2g - r - b, developed by Woebbecke et al. 1995), a hue, saturation and value (HSV) threshold and a combined ExG + HSV algorithm.

#Text=If you use the OWL in your research please consider citing this publication.  #### Investigating image-based fallow weed detection performance on Raphanus sativus and Avena sativa at speeds up to 30 km/h  The performance of the OWL from 5 - 30 km/h with different cameras and on broadleaf and grass 'weeds' was tested and published in \[Computers and Electronics in Agriculture\](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168169923008074).
#Text=The current Raspberry Pi HQ Camera + latest software combination provided a recall of 74.8% at 5 km/h and 50.5 % at 30 km/h.
#Text=Recall of up to 95.7% at 5 km/h was achieved by the global shutter Arducam AR0234.

#Text=\*\*Current\*\*  \* \[2024-05-28 - Download OWL manual\](docs/20240528\_owl\_readme.pdf)  \[View all versions\](docs)  # OWL Use Cases  ## Vehicle-mounted spot spraying  The first, and most clear use case for the OWL is for the site-specific application of herbicide in fallow.
#Text=As part of the development and testing of the unit, the OWL team designed and assembled a 2 m spot spraying boom, using two OWLs to control four 12 V solenoids each.
#Text=The boom was mounted on the back of a ute/utility vehicle with the spray tank located in the tray and powered by a 12V car battery.
#Text=Indicator lights for each nozzle were used to highlight more clearly when each solenoid had been activated for demonstration and testing purposes.

#Text=

#Text=Solenoids \| Goyen solenoid 3QH/3662 with Teejet body \| Many alternatives exist as outlined in \[#2\](https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator/issues/2) Spray tips \| Teejet TP4003E-SS \| 40 degree, flat fan nozzles, stainless steel Strainer \| TeeJet 50 mesh strainer \| Protect spray tip from clogging/damage Pump/tank \| Northstar 12V 60L ATV Sprayer \| 8.3 LPM 12V pump, 60L capacity, tray mounted  ## Robot-mounted spot spraying  A second system, identical to the first, was developed for the University of Sydney's Digifarm robot, the Agerris Digital Farm Hand.
#Text=The system is in frequent use for the site-specific control of weeds in trial areas.
#Text=It is powered by the 24V system on the robot, using a 24 - 12V DC/DC converter.

#Text=

## Image data collection The OWL can act as a high quality image data collection tool for developing image data training sets in realistic agricultural environments, attached to agricultural equipment.
#Text=The approach allows whole-image, cropped-to-bounding-box  and square images saved on a set frequency to a thumb drive.
#Text=Settings are updated in the `config.ini` file
#Text=.

#Text=Please get in contact and we can upload images of the finished systems on this page.
#Text=Check out the OWL \[Discussion\](https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator/discussions) page for any questions, suggestions ideas or feedback.

#Text=Other types of connector, layout and design are also possible, which may change the parts required.\*  ## Official OWL Hardware We now have a range of official OWL hardware available to build or purchase.  #### OWL Enclosure The Official OWL Enclosure is an extruded aluminium enclosure with rubber seals and a glued with 2mm thick glass lens.

#Text=It provides a more production friendly, durable and water/chemical resisant option over 3D printed plastic.  #### OWL Driver Board The \[Official OWL driver board\](https://github.com/geezacoleman/owl-driver-board) combines the relay control board, power supply and wiring.

#Text=It will be available for purchase soon, or you can use the files provided to order/make your own. ## Hardware Lists

Original OWL - Hardware Assembly
>⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ All components listed above are relatively "plug and play" with minimal soldering or complex electronics required.

#Text=Follow these instructions carefully and triple check your connections before powering anything on to avoid losing the \[magic smoke\](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magic\_smoke) and potentially a few hundred dollars.

#Text=Never make changes to the wiring on the detection unit while it is connected to 12V and always remain within the safe operating voltages of any component.  ## Original OWL - Hardware Assembly  A \[video guide\](https://www.youtube.com/watch?
#Text=v=vZqNKogzz8k) is available for the Original OWL assembly.
#Text=Before starting, have a look at the complete wiring diagram below to see how everything fits together.
#Text=The LEDs, fuse and Bulgin connector are all mounted on the rear of the OWL unit, rather than where they are located in the diagram.
#Text=If you prefer not to use or can't access a Bulgin connector, there is a separate 3D model design that uses cable glands instead.  !

#Text=\[wiring diagram-01\](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40649348/156698009-a58ed01b-258f-462a-9524-ba3f8d7ec246.png)  ### Step 1 - enclosure and mounts  Assembling the components for an OWL unit requires the enclosure and mounts as a minimum.
#Text=These can be 3D printed on your own printer or printed and delivered from one of the many online stores that offer a 3D printing service.
#Text=Alternatively, you could create your own enclosure using a plastic electrical box and cutting holes in it, if that's easier.
#Text=We'll be assuming you have printed out the enclosure and associated parts for the rest of the guide, but please share your finished designs however they turn out!

#Text=The first few steps don't require the enclosure so you can make a start right away, but while you're working on getting that assembled, make sure you have the pieces printing, they'll be used from Step 4.

#Text=For a complete device, you'll need: 1 x base, 1 x cover, 1 x RPi mount, 1 x relay mount, 1 x regulator mount, 1 x camera mount and 1 x plug.  ### Step 2 - soldering  There are only a few components that need soldering, including the fuse and voltage regulator:  \* Soldering of voltage regulator pins \* Soldering of 12V input wires to voltage regulator pins \* Soldering of 5V output wires to voltage regulator pins (micro USB cable) \* Soldering of red wire to both fuse terminals  Carefully check which pins on the voltage regulator correspond to 12V in, GND in, 5V out and GND out prior to soldering.
#Text=To solder the Micro USB cable to the voltage regulator output, you'll need to cut off the USB A end so you are left with approximately 10cm of cable.
#Text=Using the wire strippers or a sharp box cutter/knife, remove the rubber sheath around the wires.
#Text=If you have a data + charging cable you should see red, green, white and black wires.
#Text=The charging only cables will likely only have the red and black wires.
#Text=Isolate the red (+5V) and black (GND) wires and strip approximately 5mm off the end.
#Text=Solder the red wire to the positive output on the voltage regulator and black wire to the GND pin.
#Text=Once you have finished, it should look like the first panel in the figure below.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ Soldering can burn you and generates potentially hazardous smoke!
#Text=Use appropriate care, fume extractors and PPE to avoid any injury.
#Text=If you're new to soldering, read through \[this guide\](https://www.makerspaces.com/how-to-solder/), which explains in more detail how to perfect your skills and solder safely.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ When soldering, it's best to cover the exposed terminals with glue lined heat shrink to reduce the risk of electrical short circuits.
#Text=Voltage regulator \| Voltage regulator pins \| Fuse :-------------: \| :-------------: \| :-------------:  !
#Text=\[Vreg\](https://media.github.sydney.edu.au/user/5402/files/12c53200-ce9e-11eb-812b-52c51a0c6263) \| !

#Text=\[Fuse\](https://media.github.sydney.edu.au/user/5402/files/240e3e80-ce9e-11eb-8c0f-25e296720072)  Once the two red wires are soldered to the fuse, the fuse can be mounted on the rear panel of the OWL base.
#Text=One wire will be connected to the Bulgin plug (next step) and the other to the Wago 2-way block.
#Text=For neater wiring you can also solder jumpers between all the normally open (NO) pins on the base of the relay board, but this is optional.
#Text=If you don't solder these connections, make sure you connect wire using the screw terminals instead.
#Text=Photos of both are provided below.
#Text=Soldered \| Screw terminals :-------------: \| :-------------:  !

#Text=\[Relayboardalternative\](https://media.github.sydney.edu.au/user/5402/files/e88e7580-cf6c-11eb-8e26-7bbce2fb3f71)  The other wires requiring soldering are joins between the buzzer and jumper wires for easy connection to the GPIO pins and from the LEDs to the power in/jumper wires.  ### Step 3 - wiring up Bulgin connector  Next we'll need to wire the output relay control and input 12V wires to the Bulgin panel mount connector.
#Text=Fortunately all pins are labelled, so follow the wire number table below.
#Text=This will need to be repeated for the Bulgin plug as well, which will connect your solenoids or other devices to the relay control board.
#Text=The process is:  1.
#Text=Connect all wires to Bulgin connector using the screw terminals 2.
#Text=Mount the connector to the rear panel 3.
#Text=Leave at least 10cm of wire so it can be connected to the relay board and other connections later.

#Text=Bulgin terminal number \| Wire connection :-------------: \| :-------------:  1 \| Blue wire - connects to centre terminal (common) on relay 1 2 \| Green wire - connects to centre terminal (common) on relay 2 3 \| Orange wire - connects to centre terminal (common) on relay 3 4 \| White wire - connects to centre terminal (common) on relay 4 5 \| Red 12VDC - connects to fuse wire already soldered.
#Text=Make sure wire is the right length when mounted.  6 \| Black GND - connects to Wago 2-way terminal  >⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ Skip this step if you're using cable glands.

#Text=Once all the wires have been connected you can now mount the Bulgin connector to the OWL base.  ### Step 4 - mounting the relay control board and voltage regulator  Attach the relay control board to the 3D printed relay control board mount using 2.5 mm standoffs.
#Text=Attach the voltage regulator to the 3D printed voltage regulator mount with 2 mm standoffs.
#Text=The mounted voltage regulator can then be mounted to one corner of the relay control board.
#Text=The relay board and voltage regulator can then be installed in the raised slots in the OWL base.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ Use \*\*2.5 mm\*\* standoffs for mounting the relay control board to its base.
#Text=Use \*\*2 mm\*\* standoffs to mount the voltage regulator to its base.  !

#Text=\[Relaymount\](https://media.github.sydney.edu.au/user/5402/files/964c5500-cf6a-11eb-8d2f-e1282b6411c3)  ### Step 5 - wiring the relay control board, voltage regulator, Wago 2-way blocks and Bulgin connector  Connect the relay control board to the Bulgin connector using the table in step 3 as a guide.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ Some relay control boards such as \[this\](https://www.amazon.com/ELEGOO-Channel-Optocoupler-Arduino-Raspberry/dp/B01HEQF5HU/ref=asc\_df\_B01HEQF5HU/?

#Text=tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=198076677096&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=5997956897740931812&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9027902&hvtargid=pla-350609711896&psc=1) on Amazon are ACTIVE on LOW.
#Text=This means that the signal provided by the Raspberry Pi (a higher voltage) to activate a relay will instead turn the relay off.

#Text=While this can be changed in the code, please consider purchasing HIGH level trigger ( e.g \[the board specified in the parts list\](https://www.jaycar.com.au/arduino-compatible-4-channel-12v-relay-module/p/XC4440)) or adjustable trigger ( e.g.
#Text=\[this board\](https://www.amazon.com/DZS-Elec-Optocoupler-Isolation-Triggered/dp/B07BDJJTLZ/ref=asc\_df\_B07BDJJTLZ/?
#Text=tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=241912880102&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=5997956897740931812&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9027902&hvtargid=pla-438273746158&psc=1)).
#Text=Next, connect red and black jumper wires to the VCC and GND header pins on the relay control board.
#Text=Now choose one Wago block to be a 12V positive block and the second to be the negative or ground.

#Text=To the positive block, connect the 12 V wire from the fuse (12V input from source), the 12 V input to the voltage regulator, the 12 V solenoid line from the relay board and the VCC line from the relay board to one of the two WAGO terminal blocks, twisting the wires together if necessary.

#Text=Repeat with the second, negative WAGO terminal block, connecting the input ground line from the Bulgin connector, ground line from the voltage regulator and the GND black wire from the relay board.

#Text=We provide a mounting plate that can be used with both the HQ, Global Shutter or V2 cameras, however, we recommend the use of the HQ camera for improved image clarity.
#Text=Attach the HQ camera to the 3D printed mount using 2.5 mm standoffs (or 2 mm standoffs if using the V2 camera).

#Text=Ensuring that the CSI cable port on the camera is directed towards the Raspberry Pi, mount the camera inside the OWL case using four M3 standoffs (50 mm long for HQ camera\; 20 mm long for V2 camera).

#Text=For simplicity we have used two 12V LEDs (which are just normal LEDs with a current limiting resistor included) for both the 5V TX/GND connection for Raspberry Pi status indication and also the 12V power connection.

Compact OWL - Hardware Assembly
One major benefit of the Compact OWL (with the OWL driver board) is that no soldering is required.
#Text=The design removes  much of the wiring, improving ease of assembly and reliability.

#Text=If you choose a Raspberry Pi Relay HAT instead of the  OWL driver board, you'll just need to add a voltage regulator and solder that in to provide the 5V @ 5A required for  the Raspberry Pi 5 or up to 3A required for the older models.
#Text=There are two options for the enclosure.
#Text=The 3D printed enclosure and the official OWL extruded aluminium enclosure.
#Text=Both share a 3D printed tray and the same components.
#Text=The 3D printed version allows you to make a start without needing to buy bespoke components if you have access to a 3D printer.
#Text=The 3D model files for the printed enclosure can be downloaded \[here\]().
#Text=The Official OWL Enclosure will be available for purchase through the OWL store soon
#Text=.

#Text=By default the OWL HAT is wired as shown above:  ```ini \[Relays\] # defines the relay ID (left) that matches to a boardpin (right) on the Pi. # Only change if you rewire/change the relay connections. 0 = 13 1 = 15 2 = 16 3 = 18 ``` The final jumper pin `Pi Power Supply Enable` connects the Raspberry Pi to the 5V provided by the HAT.

#Text=Only connect this jumper once you want the  Pi to start.  #### Step 2a - connecting a generic relay HAT  Instead of the Official OWL HAT, a relay control HAT (such as \[this from PiHut\](https://core-electronics.com.au/pirelay-v2-relay-board-for-raspberry-pi-1.html?))
#Text=can be used, with some minor changes to the OWL software.
#Text=There are many different relay HATs available, so check which is most suitable for your purposes.
#Text=Be sure to choose one with accessible GPIO pins.
#Text=Fit the HAT as recommended by the manufacturer, similar to the below images (source: The PiHut)
#Text=.
#Text=\[image\](https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator/assets/51358498/bf16cf89-0955-4822-8a8a-c3bd7c295c7f)   \|    !

#Text=\[image\](https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator/assets/51358498/4c0987a7-936f-4338-ac72-6ee352bc2636)           \|  In its default configuration, this specific relay HAT assigns GPIO boardpins 29, 31, 33, and 35 to relays 4 - 1 respectively.
#Text=This differs to the default OWL configuration, so the `\[Relays\]` section of the config file would need to be updated.

#Text=Using this board as the example:  ```ini \[Relays\] # defines the relay ID (left) that matches to a boardpin (right) on the Pi. # Only change if you rewire/change the relay connections. 0 = 35 1 = 33 2 = 31 3 = 29 ```  However, if you use another relay HAT check the assignment/configuration of relays to boardpins.
#Text=For reference, use this  GPIO guide to help.

#### Step 2b - connecting the voltage regulator Without the OWL HAT, 5V power to Pi needs to be supplied separately.

#Text=We recommend the \[Pololu 5V 5.5A step down voltage regulator\](https://core-electronics.com.au/pololu-5v-5-5a-step-down-voltage-regulator-d36v50f5.html), however,  there are many options available.
#Text=Solder wires to the input and output of the voltage regulator.
#Text=Using WAGO connector blocks, connect the input to the 12V from the Amphenol connector.
#Text=Mount the regulator to the underside of the internal tray using M2 standoffs.

#Text=

##### Raspberry Pi 3B+ or 4B The earlier models of the Raspberry Pi consumer less power (3A @ 5V) than the Raspberry Pi 5 and can be powered over single 5V and GND pins on the GPIO.
#Text=Use high quality connectors here or consider soldering directly to the GPIO pins on the HAT.
#Text=A good connection without risk of coming loose, is critical.
#Text=You'll need to solder to pins 2 (5V) and 6 (GND) on the relay HAT.
#Text=More details provided  \[here\](https://thepihut.com/blogs/raspberry-pi-tutorials/how-do-i-power-my-raspberry-pi) from The PiHut (image source).

#Text=

##### Raspberry Pi 5 The Raspberry Pi 5 consumes up to 5A @ 5V, so it's suggested to use 2 x 5V and 2 x GND pins on the Raspberry Pi.
#Text=Some good information on the topic is provided \[here\](https://forums.raspberrypi.com/viewtopic.php?
#Text=Using the two 5V outputs from the voltage regulator, solder one +5V wire to pin 2 and another to pin 4 on the GPIO on  the HAT relay.
#Text=Similarly, connect two GND wires from the voltage regulator output to pins 30 and 34.
#Text=Ensure there is a  good solder connection, without any short circuits to neighbouring pins.
#Text=The images below are from a Raspberry Pi 5, however, the setup is the same for the 4B and 3B+ models just with one 5V/GND wire
#Text=.
#Text=\[relay\_hat\_1\_crop\](https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator/assets/51358498/dc678435-e59a-44ae-a2d8-4eab43c7797c) \| !

#Text=qs=ulEaXIWI0c8tWp%252BkBCr3Ag%3D%3D).
#Text=The connector has 3 x 16 guage connections rated to 13A and 3 x 20  guage rated up to 7.5A (machined) or 5A (stamped).
#Text=Use the appropriate crimp connections for the 16 and 20 guage connections.

#Text=

Connections are labeled A - F on the receptacle and should be made in the following order: 1. +12V (red) - A 2.

#Text=GND (black) - E 3. relay 1 (blue) - B 4. relay 2 (green) - C 5. relay 3 (orange) - D 6. relay 4 (white) - F  Unlike the relay HATs and relay board in the Original OWL, the common ground for the OWL driver board is routed through  the board itself, reducing the wiring required.
#Text=Connect the wires from the back of the connector to each relay,  using the above list as a guide.
#Text=The finished result should appear similar to the images below.
#Text=Add heat shrink at  the end of each wire for neater and more reliable connections
#Text=.

#Text=Connect the 5 V and ground wires  to Raspberry Pi GPIO pins 7 and 9, respectively.
#Text=The buzzer is useful for identifying when the OWL has started successfully.
#Text=It isn't essential to operation.

### Optional Step - connecting 12V solenoids Once you have completed the setup, you now have the opportunity to wire up your own solenoids for spot spraying, targeted tillage, spot flaming or any other targeted weed control you can dream up.

#Text=To do this, wire the GND wire of your device (it can be any wire if it's a solenoid) to the ground pin on the Bulgin plug (the same wire used for the GND from the 12V power source) and wire the other to one of the blue, green, orange or white wires on pins 1 - 4.

#Text=</details>  # Software  The project will eventually support the use of the two major embedded computing devices, the Raspberry Pi (models 3B+, 4 and 5) and the Jetson Nano/Jetson Xavier NX for possible green-on-green detection with deep learning algorithms.
#Text=At present, just the details on setting up the Raspberry Pi 3B+/4/5 are provided below.
#Text=There are two options for installation.
#Text=For the first, all you'll need to do is download the disk image file (vX.X.X-owl.img) and flash it to an SD card.
#Text=The second method is more in depth, but takes you through the entire process from beginning to end.
#Text=If you're looking to learn about how everything works, take some time to work through this process.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ 08/05/2024 - OWL transitioned from `picamera` to `picamera2` support.
#Text=The v1.0.0 disk image below (Buster) does not support `picamera2` and will not work on the Raspberry Pi 5 nor with the recent camera releases.
#Text=We strongly recommend using the most up to date version of Raspbian with the latest OWL software.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ 17/03/2023 - running of the OWL changed from using `greenonbrown.py` to `owl.py`.

#Text=For this method you'll need access to: \* Desktop/laptop computer \* Micro SD card reader \* Internet with large data capacity and high speed (WARNING: the image file is large, and downloading will take time and use up a substantial quantity of your data allowance if you have are on a limited plan)
Quick method for software installation
### Step 1 - download the disk image file Download the entire disk image file (v1.0.0-owl.img) here: \[OWL disk image\](https://www.dropbox.com/s/ad6uieyk3awav9k/owl.img.zip?
#Text=dl=0) (NOT COMPATIBLE WITH RASPBERRY PI 5)  >⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ The v1.0.0-owl.img file contains the original software and we strongly recommend updating using the process below.
#Text=It also includes the deprecated naming of `greenonbrown.py` instead of `owl.py`.
#Text=If you do not update the software, be aware that you will need to run `greenonbrown.py` instead.

#Text=The latest, stable version will be linked above, however, all other older versions or versions with features being tested are available \[here\](#version-history).  ### Step 2 - flash owl.img to SD card  The easiest way to flash (add the vX.X.X-owl.img file to the SD card so it can boot) the SD card is to use Balena Etcher or any other card flashing software.
#Text=Instructions for Balena Etcher are provided here.
#Text=Navigate to the \[website\](https://www.balena.io/etcher/) and download the relevant version/operating system.
#Text=Install Balena Etcher and fire it up.  !

#Text=\[OWL - etcher\](https://media.github.sydney.edu.au/user/3859/files/e184ea00-d5a0-11eb-9560-4842758686d0)  \* Insert the SD card using your SD card reader. \* Select `Flash from file` on the Balena Etcher window and navigate to where you downloaded the vXX-XX-XX-owl.dmg file.
#Text=This can be a zip file (compressed) too. \* Select the target, the SD card you just inserted. \* Click `Flash`  If this completes successfully, you're ready to move to the next step.

#Text=If it fails, use Balena Etcher documentation to diagnose the issue.  ### Step 3 - power up  Once the SD card is inserted into the slot of the Raspberry Pi, power everything up and wait for the beep.

#Text=If you hear the beep, you're ready to go and start focusing the camera.  ### Step 4 - updating the disk image  The disk image that you downloaded is likely to be a few versions behind the most recent.
#Text=We only provide images of the most major updates.
#Text=So to update the OWL software, just run the follow these steps.  1.
#Text=Have the OWL powered on with screen, keyboard and mouse connected.
#Text=You should see a desktop with the OWL logo. 2.
#Text=Press CTRL + ALT + T to open a Terminal window or click the black icon with blue line and >\_ symbol. 3.

#Text=Once the Terminal window is open, make sure you are working in the `owl` virtual environment by running:  ``` owl@raspberrypi:~ $ workon owl (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ ```  Notice that (owl) now appears before the line in the Terminal window.
#Text=This indicates you are in the `owl` virtual environment.
#Text=This is \*\*critical\*\* to make sure you install everything in the `requirements.txt` file into the right spot.  4.

#Text=Once you are in the `owl` environment, enter these commands on each new line:  ``` (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ cd ~ (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ mv owl owl-old      # this renames the old 'owl' folder to 'owl-old' (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ git clone https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator        # download the new software (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ mv OpenWeedLocator owl      # rename the download to 'owl' (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ cd ~/owl (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~/owl $ pip install -r requirements.txt                # installs the necessary software into the (owl) environment  (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~/owl $ chmod a+x owl.py                  # changes owl.py to be executable (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~/owl $ chmod a+x owl\_boot.sh                     # changes owl\_boot.sh to be executable ```  Once this is complete your software will be up to date and you can move on to focusing the camera.  ### Step 5 - focusing the camera  The final step in the process is to make sure the camera is correctly focused for the mounting height.
#Text=With the latest software, when you run `owl.py --focus` a sharpness (i.e. least blurry) estimation is provided on the video feed.
#Text=The algorithm determines how sharp an image is, so the higher the value the better.
#Text=A single script is provided to make focusing as easy as possible.
#Text=Simply run:   ``` (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ cd ~/owl (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~/owl $ bash focus\_owl.sh   ```  This will automate all the steps below.
#Text=If this doesn't work, follow the steps below.
#Text=If you would like to focus the OWL again, you can always run `.
#Text=/owl.py --focus`
#Text=.
#Text=\[blurry owl\](https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator/assets/51358498/34ae71f2-8507-4892-b49a-195e515e56dd) \| !

#Text=\[clear owl\](https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator/assets/51358498/20db536b-edaf-4085-a613-6ea786747998) \|  #### Manual focusing  With the older versions of the software, you need to stop all `owl.py` or `greenonbrown.py` background processes before you can restart the software with the video feed viewable on the screen.

#Text=Enter the following into the terminal:  ``` (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ ps -C owl.py # or ps -C greenonbrown.py if you still have the older version. ```  After pressing ENTER, you should receive the following output:  ``` (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ ps -C owl.py PID TTY              TIME CMD 515 ?
#Text=00:00:00 owl.py ```  The PID is the important part, it's the ID number for the `owl.py` program.
#Text=In this case it is `515`, but it is likely to be different on your OWL.
#Text=IMPORTANT: If the headings `PID TTY              TIME CMD` appear but a PID/line for owl.py doesn't appear it could mean two things.
#Text=Firstly make sure you've typed `owl.py` correctly.
#Text=If it doesn't have the right program to look for, it won't find it.
#Text=The other option is that `owl.py` isn't running, which may also be the case.
#Text=If you're certain it's not running in the background, skip the stop program step below, and move straight to launching `owl.py`.
#Text=If a PID appears, you'll need to stop it operating.

#Text=To stop the program, enter the following command:  ``` (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ sudo kill enter\_your\_PID\_number\_here ```  The program should now be stopped  Now you'll need to launch `owl.py` manually with the video feed visible.
#Text=To do this use the Terminal window and type the following commands:  ``` (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ ~/owl/.
#Text=/owl.py --show-display ```  This will bring up a video feed you can use to visualise the OWL detector and also use it to focus the camera.

#Text=Once you're happy with the focus, press Esc to exit.  ### OPTIONAL Step 6 - enabling UART for status LED  This is just the cherry on top and non-essential to correct operation of the OWL but to make sure the status LED you connected earlier blinks correctly the GPIO UART needs to be enabled.
#Text=Open up a terminal console by pressing `Ctrl + T`.
#Text=Type:  ``` (owl) owl@raspberrypi :-$ sudo nano /boot/config.txt ```  This will open up the config.txt file.

#Text=Scroll down to the bottom by holding the down arrow key and add the following line to the very last line of the file:  ``` enable\_uart=1 ```  Press `ctrl + x` to exit, then type `y` to save and then `enter`.
#Text=You're now ready to run!

#Text=### OPTIONAL Step 7 - running original `greenonbrown.py`  If you are using the v1.0.0-owl.img file and don't update the OWL software as above, you will be using the original `greenonbrown.py` Python script.
#Text=Running it from the command line will require slightly different commands.
#Text=Please follow this guide if this is you.
#Text=In the `greenonbrown.py` file there is a parameter `headless` which determines if a video is shown.
#Text=If set to `True` a video feed is NOT displayed and the system will operate whenever it is powered on.
#Text=If it is set to `False` a video feed will be displayed.
#Text=To change this parameter, scroll to the bottom of `greenonbrown.py` and find the line `headless=True`.
#Text=Change as desired.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ `headless` must be set to `True` for operation without a screen.
#Text=If a screen is not attached but `headless=False` the Raspberry Pi will not boot correctly and the OWL software will not run.

#Text=To run the software from the command line (assuming it is not currently running), follow these steps:  ``` owl@raspberrypi:~ $ workon owl (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ cd owl  (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ /owl $ .
#Text=/greenonbrown.py   ```  >⚠️\*\*BUG ALERT\*\*⚠️ There is a known bug with this version where the script will not run if you are running it outside of the `owl` directory.
#Text=If you enocunter this error, `cd` into the `owl` directory and run the code again.

#Text=</details>    ## Detailed Method \*\*IMPORTANT\*\*: \*Suitable for the Raspberry Pi 5 and Bookworm Raspberry Pi OS.\*  This setup approach may take a little longer (aproximately 1 hour total) than the quick method, but you'll be much better trained in the ways of OWL and more prepared for any problem solving, upgrades or changes in the future.
#Text=You'll also download and use the latest software that hasn't been saved in the .img file yet.
#Text=In the process you'll learn about Python environments, install Python packages and set it all up to run on startup.

#Text=To get this working you'll need access to: \* Raspberry Pi \* Empty SD Card (SanDisk 32GB SDXC ideally) \* Your own computer with SD card reader \* Power supply (if not using the OWL unit) \* Screen and keyboard \* WiFi/Ethernet cable
Detailed OWL installation procedure
### Step 1 - Raspberry Pi setup #### Step 1a - Rasperry Pi OS Before powering up the Raspberry Pi, you'll need to install the Raspian operating system (just like Windows/MacOSX for laptops) on the new SD card.
#Text=This is done using the same process as the quick method used to flash the premade owl.img file, except you'll be doing it with a completely new and untouched version of Raspbian.

#Text=From your own computer, download and flash the latest \*\*64-bit\*\* version of Raspian from the official  \[Raspberry Pi website\](https://www.raspberrypi.com/software/operating-systems/#raspberry-pi-os-64-bit) to the empty SD card.
#Text=The official \[Raspberry Pi Imager\](https://www.raspberrypi.com/software/) is a good piece of software to use.
#Text=Leave the hostname as default.
#Text=To simplify setup, you can specify the wifi network settings.
#Text=Set the username to 'owl' and choose a password
#Text=.
#Text=\[Raspberry Pi Imager\](https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator/assets/51358498/a86a6358-3a8c-4f40-94df-9eeba9c17e4d) \| !

#Text=\[Imager\](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/10a74429-fc12-49a6-a9df-cc67a55dab0c) \|  #### Step 1b - Setting up the OWL Once the Raspian OS has been flashed to the SD Card (may take 5 - 10 minutes), remove the SD card and insert it into the Raspberry Pi.
#Text=Connect the screen, keyboard and mouse and then power up the Pi.
#Text=Alternatively, you can SSH into your OWL from a separate device and install it remotely.

#Text=A good guide on how to do that is  available \[here\](https://www.makeuseof.com/how-to-ssh-into-raspberry-pi-remote/).   ##### First boot On the first boot you may be asked to set country, timezone, keyboard, connect to wifi and look for updates among other things.
#Text=If you haven't already set the username, set it to 'owl' and choose a password.
#Text=Uninstall the unused browser -  this will save space on the Pi.
#Text=Finally, you will be asked to restart the pi.  ##### Opening terminal After the restart, open up Terminal.
#Text=You can press CTRL + ALT + T, or click the icon in the top left with the `>\_`  symbol.

#Text=The instructions that follow are a blend of those available from  \[PyImageSearch\](https://pyimagesearch.com/2019/09/16/install-opencv-4-on-raspberry-pi-4-and-raspbian-buster/)  and \[QEngineering\](https://qengineering.eu/bookworm.html)  >⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ All commands below are provided for easy copy/paste.
#Text=When using terminal you should see `owl@raspberrypi:~ $` > at the start of each line and `(owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $` when operating within the `owl` virtual environment.
#Text=Pay very close > attention to the presence/absence of `(owl)` in front of each line, as this can make/break installation.

#Text=>⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ We recommend naming the device `owl` when asked if you didn't set it during the flashing process.   #### Two-line Install If you prefer a faster and simpler installation, try the following two-line install.
#Text=You'll first need to clone the owl repository before running `owl\_setup.sh`.

#Text=To start, clone the Github repository: ```commandline git clone https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator owl ``` With the repository cloned into the 'owl' folder, we can now run the bash script `owl\_setup.sh`.
#Text=This will take some time to complete  ```commandline bash owl/owl\_setup.sh ``` Once completed successfully, your OWL is ready to go.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ If you use this method, you can finish the installation here.
#Text=The following steps just go through what is  > in the `owl\_setup.sh` script step-by-step.

#Text=We recommend the step-by-step approach if you want to become more familiar > with how the OWL works.  #### Step-by-step install Instead of the two-line installation, the following procedure details all steps required.  ##### Free up space The Raspberry Pi comes pre-installed with a range of software.
#Text=To free up space it can be removed from the OWL.
#Text=Depending on your install, these may or may not be present.

#Text=At the command line (it should look like `owl@raspberrypi:~ $`),  run the following: ```commandline sudo apt-get purge wolfram-engine ``` ```commandline sudo apt-get purge libreoffice\* ``` ```commandline sudo apt-get clean ``` ```commandline sudo apt-get autoremove ``` ##### Set up the virtual environment A virtual environment contains all the necessary packages in one neat spot.
#Text=We'll be using `virtualenv` and  `virtualenvwrapper` on the Pi to create a virtual environment called `owl`.
#Text=To start with, update the system.
#Text=The update may take a few minutes depending on your internet connection and how many packages need updating.
#Text=It's good practice to do this regularly.
#Text=Then you'll add the following two lines to the `bashrc` file.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*WARNING\*\*⚠️ using `rpi-update` will update to the latest kernel and drivers.
#Text=This is to fix an issue with image component order.
#Text=The problem should eventually be merged into normal `apt-get update && upgrade`.
#Text=This notice will be removed then.
#Text=Begin by updating the system: ```commandline sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get upgrade ``` Now, update to the latest firmware version to fix the issue between RGB and BGR channel ordering.
#Text=```commandline sudo rpi-update ``` Then add the following lines to the `.bashrc` file to prepare for the creation of virtual environments.

#Text=```commandline echo "# virtualenv and virtualenvwraper" >> ~/.bashrc ``` ```commandline echo "export VIRTUALENVWRAPPER\_PYTHON=/usr/bin/python" >> ~/.bashrc ``` Finally, reload the `.bashrc` file.
#Text=```commandline source ~/.bashrc ``` Once that is complete, you can install `virtualenv` and `virtualenvwrapper` and add a few more lines to the same `bashrc` file.

#Text=```commandline sudo apt-get install python3-virtualenv ``` ```commandline sudo apt-get install python3-virtualenvwrapper ``` Following the installation of these packages, add the following lines to the `.bashrc` file.

#Text=```commandline echo "export WORKON\_HOME=$HOME/.virtualenvs" >> ~/.bashrc ``` ```commandline echo "source /usr/share/virtualenvwrapper/virtualenvwrapper.sh" >> ~/.bashrc ``` As above, reload the file to update the changes.
#Text=```commandline source ~/.bashrc ``` With the virtual environment software successfully installed, it's now time to create the `owl` environment.
#Text=Importantly, we need to inherit the site-packages (i.e. everything currently on the Pi) because they contain `picamera2` pre-installed.
#Text=To make the `owl` environment, run the following: ```commandline mkvirtualenv --system-site-packages -p python owl ``` The command line should now look like `(owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $`.
#Text=The '(owl)' at the start of the line means you're currently within that virtual environment.
#Text=To turn it off you can run `deactivate` and to turn it run `workon owl`.
#Text=\*\*IMPORTANT\*\*: The next steps must be run within the `owl` virtual environment.
#Text=We're installing packages specific to the OWL.  ### Step 2 - Installing packages We now need to install the Python libraries that let the OWL work.
#Text=The most import is OpenCV, which we'll do first before downloading the OWL repository and installing the remainder from the `requirements.txt` file.
#Text=Begin by ensuring the `owl` environment is active.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*WARNING\*\*⚠️ It is ESSENTIAL that `(owl)` is present at the start of each line in terminal for this section.
#Text=The `(owl)` > indicates that you are within the `owl` virtual environment and that these Python packages will be installed and accessible > within this environment.
#Text=Run `workon owl` to ensure you are in the `owl` environment.
#Text=```commandline workon owl ``` Now that you are in the `owl` virtual environment we can begin installing packages.
#Text=```commandline pip3 install opencv-contrib-python ``` This should have successfully installed OpenCV into the `owl` virtual environment.

#Text=You can double check by quickly starting a Python session at the command line: ```commandline python ``` This will open up an interactive Python session (indicated by >>>) from which you should type:  ```commandline >>> import cv2 >>> import picamera2 >>> exit() ``` This should then exit you from the Python session.

#Text=The command line should look like this:  ```commandline (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ ```  If both of these complete without error, then you've successfully set up the virtual environment and installed OpenCV.  ### Step 3 - Downloading the 'owl' repository  Now you should have:  \* A virtual environment called 'owl' \* A working version of OpenCV installed into that environment \* a Terminal window open with the 'owl' environment activated.
#Text=The next step is to download the entire OpenWeedLocator repository into your \*home\* directory on the Raspberry Pi.

#Text=First change into the home directory:  ```commandline cd ~ ``` then clone the repository 'https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator' into a new folder called 'owl' ```commandline git clone https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator owl ``` This will download the repository into a folder called `owl`.
#Text=Double check it is there by typing `(owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ ls`  and reading through the results, alternatively open up the Home folder using a mouse.
#Text=If that was successful, you can  now move on to Step 4.  ### Step 4 - Installing the OWL Python dependencies Dependencies are Python packages on which the code relies to function correctly.
#Text=With a range of versions and possible comptibility issues, this is the step where issues might come up.
#Text=There aren't too many packages, but please make sure each and every module in the requirements.txt file has been installed correctly.

#Text=These include:  \* OpenCV (should already be in 'owl' virtual environment from Step 1) \* numpy \* imutils \* gpiozero \* pandas \* RPi.GPIO \* tqdm \* blessed (for command line visualisation) \* threading, multiprocessing, collections, queue, time, os (though these are included as standard Python modules).
#Text=>⚠️\*\*IMPORTANT\*\*⚠️ Before continuing make sure you are in the `owl` virtual environment.
#Text=Check that `(owl)` appears at the start of each command line, e.g.
#Text=`(owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $`.
#Text=Run `workon owl` if you are unsure.
#Text=If you are not in the `owl` environment, you will run into errors when starting `owl.py`.

#Text=To install all the requirements.txt, change into the owl directory:  ```commandline cd ~/owl ```  then run:  ```commandline pip install -r requirements.txt ``` Now to double-check this has worked, we can open up another Python session and try importing the packages.
#Text=Begin by typing:  ```commandline python ``` Python should start up an interactive session\; type each of these in and make sure you don't get any errors.
#Text=```commandline >>> import cv2 >>> import numpy >>> import gpiozero >>> import pandas ``` Version numbers can be checked with:  ```commandline >>> print(package\_name\_here.
#Text=\_\_version\_\_) ## this is a generic example - add the package where it says package\_name\_here >>> print(cv2.

#Text=\_\_version\_\_) >>> exit() ``` If any errors appear, you'll need to go back and check that the modules above have (1) been installed into the owl virtual environment, (2) that Python was started in the owl environment, and/or (3) they all installed correctly.

#Text=Once that is complete, exit Python and continue with the installation process.  ### Step 5 - starting OWL on boot  Now that these dependencies have been installed into the owl virtual environment, it's time to make sure the software  runs on startup.
#Text=The first step is to make both the Python file `owl.py` and the boot files `owl\_boot.sh` and `owl\_boot\_wrapper.sh` executable.
#Text=Then move both `owl\_boot.sh` and `owl\_boot\_wrapper.sh` into the `/usr/local/bin` directory.

#Text=```commandline chmod a+x owl.py ``` ```commandline chmod a+x owl\_boot.sh ``` ```commandline chmod a+x owl\_boot\_wrapper.sh ``` ```commandline sudo mv owl\_boot.sh /usr/local/bin/owl\_boot.sh ``` ```commandline sudo mv owl\_boot\_wrapper.sh /usr/local/bin/owl\_boot\_wrapper.sh ```  After they have been made executable, the `owl.py` needs to be launched on startup so each time the Raspberry Pi is powered on, the detection systems starts.
#Text=The easiest way to do this is by using cron, a scheduler for starting code.
#Text=We need to add the `owl\_boot.sh` file to the schedule so that it launches on boot.
#Text=The `owl\_boot.sh` file is  fairly straightforward.

#Text=It's what's known as a \[bash script\](https://ryanstutorials.net/bash-scripting-tutorial/bash-script.php) which is just a text file that contains commands we would normally enter on the command line in Terminal.
#Text=This is the `owl\_boot.sh` file: ```commandline #!

#Text=/bin/bash  # automatically determine the home directory, to avoid issues with username source $HOME/.bashrc  # activate the 'owl' virtual environment source $HOME/.virtualenvs/owl/bin/activate  # change directory to the owl folder cd $HOME/owl  # run owl.py in the background and save the log output LOG\_DATE=$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H-%M-%SZ") .

#Text=/owl.py > $HOME\_DIR/owl/logs/owl\_$LOG\_DATE.log 2>&1 & ```  In the file, the first two commands launch our `owl` virtual environment, then we change directory `cd` into the owl  folder and run the python program.
#Text=The `owl\_boot\_wrapper.sh` file figures out which user is running the file, and then uses that user to run `owl\_boot.sh`.
#Text=This makes the system more resilient to changes in Pi username.
#Text=To add this to the list of cron jobs, you'll need to edit it as a root user:  ```commandline sudo crontab -e ```  Select `1.
#Text=/bin/nano editor`, which should bring up the crontab file.
#Text=At the base of the file add this text:  ``` @reboot /usr/local/bin/owl\_boot\_wrapper.sh > /home/launch.log 2>&1  ```  Once you've added that line, you'll just need to save the file and exit.
#Text=In the nano editor just press Ctrl + X, then Y and finally press Enter to agree to save and exit.

#Text=If you get stuck, \[this guide\](https://www.makeuseof.com/how-to-run-a-raspberry-pi-program-script-at-startup/) or \[this guide\](https://www.tomshardware.com/how-to/run-script-at-boot-raspberry-pi) both have a bit more detail on cron and some other methods too.
#Text=Now you'll just need to reboot the system.

#Text=Once it reboots, `owl.py` will launch and run in the background.  ### Step 6 - focusing the camera  >⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️ \*Cameras with automatic focus such as the Raspberry Pi Camera Module 3 will be automatically focused to 1.2m  distance.

#Text=The following guide is useful for the HQ and Global Shutter cameras which require manual focusing.\*  The final step in the process is to make sure the camera is correctly focused for the mounting height.
#Text=With the latest software, when you run `owl.py --focus` a sharpness (i.e. least blurry) estimation is provided on the video feed.

#Text=00:00:00 owl.py ```  The PID is the important part, it's the ID number for the `owl.py` program.
#Text=In this case it is `515`, but it is likely to be different on your OWL.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*IMPORTANT\*\*⚠️ If the headings `PID TTY              TIME CMD` appear but a PID/line for owl.py doesn't appear it could mean two things.

#Text=If it doesn't have the right program to look for, it won't find it.
#Text=The other option is that `owl.py` isn't running, which may also be the case.
#Text=If you're certain it's not running in the background, skip the stop program step below, and move straight to launching `owl.py`.
#Text=If a PID appears, you'll need to stop it operating.

#Text=To stop the program, enter the following command:  ``` (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ sudo kill enter\_your\_PID\_number\_here ```  The program should now be stopped  Now you'll need to launch `owl.py` manually with the video feed visible.
#Text=To do this use the Terminal window and type the following commands:  ``` (owl) owl@raspberrypi:~ $ ~/owl/.
#Text=/owl.py --show-display ```  This will bring up a video feed you can use to visualise the OWL detector and also use it to focus the camera.
#Text=Once you're happy with the focus, press Esc to exit.  ### Step 8 - reboot  The moment of truth.
#Text=Shut the Raspberry Pi down and unplug the power.

#Text= ## Changing detection settings
Instructions for changing detection settings
Changing detection settings is now easier by using a specific config file.
#Text=You can use command line flags to toggle display, data source and setting focus.
#Text=Use the `config.ini` file in the  config folder to set other parameters as described below.
#Text=The default config file is `DAY\_SENSITIVITY\_2.ini` (details provided below).
#Text=If you change any settings here, make sure to save the file before restarting `owl.py`.
#Text=While we recommend tuning detection parameters to your specific environment, we have provided three sensitivity levels to  get you started
#Text=.

#Text=\| Config File Name      \| Description                                                                                                                                          \| \|-----------------------\|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\| \| DAY\_SENSITIVITY\_1.ini \| The least sensitive parameters, designed to minimise false positive detections to just get the big weeds.
#Text=Minimum detection size has been increased. \| \| DAY\_SENSITIVITY\_2.ini \| OWL detection parameters were tuned to this file
#Text=.
#Text=\| \| DAY\_SENSITIVITY\_3.ini \| The most sensitive parameters.
#Text=Reduce missed detections with lower minimum detection size and wider detection ranges
#Text=.
#Text=\|   ### Command line flags Command line flags are let you specify options on the command line within the Terminal window.
#Text=It means you don't have to open up the code and make changes directly.
#Text=OWL now supports the use of flags for some parameters.

#Text=To read a description of all flags available type `--help`:  ```commandline usage: owl.py \[-h\] \[--input\] \[--show-display\] \[--focus\]   --input               path to image directory, single image or video file   --show-display        show display windows   --focus               focus the camera ```  ### Creating your own config files Feel free to create your own config files to meet your specific conditions.
#Text=In `owl.py` just update the path to the config file.
#Text=Follow the same layout and format as the default.
#Text=To open `owl.py`, you'll need to open it and not execute the file.

#Text= ## Green-on-Green
How to detect in-crop weeds with the OWL
### OWL Integration Green-on-Green capability is (almost) here!
#Text=While we previously had implemented in-crop detection models with the Google Coral and Pycoral, the lack of support has made us reconsider that approach.
#Text=Running detection models like YOLO is in the works to run on the base Raspberry Pi 5 or with additional hardware such as the Raspberry Pi AI Kit with the Hailo 8L.

#Text=If you would like to try the Google Coral, you can by following the instructions in the 'models' directory.   ### Model Training  Effective models need training data, so if you're interested in using the Green-on-Green functionality, you will need to start collecting and annotating images of relevant weeds for training.
#Text=Alternatively, head over to \[Weed-AI\](https://weed-ai.sydney.edu.au/explore?
#Text=is\_head\_filter=%5B%22latest+version%22%5D) to see if any image data may be relevant for your purposes.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*NOTE\*\*⚠️There do appear to be some issues with the exporting functionality of YOLOv5/v8 to .tflite models for use with the Coral.
#Text=The issue has been raised on the Ultralytics repository and should hopefully be resolved soon.
#Text=You can follow the updates \[here\](https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics/issues/1312).

#Text=\[YOLOv8\](https://github.com/ultralytics/ultralytics) and \[YOLOv5\](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5) currently provide the most user friendly methods of training, optimisation and exporting as `.tflite` files for use with the Google Coral.
#Text=There is also a Weed-AI Google Colab Notebook which can be used to train models from Weed-AI data directly.

#Text= ## Non-Raspberry Pi Installation
Installing OWL software on a non-Raspberry Pi system
Using OWL software on your laptop/desktop or other non-Raspberry Pi system is a great way to test, develop and learn more about how it works.
#Text=To start using the software, just follow the steps below.
#Text=You will need access to virtual environments and your IDE/editor of choice.

#Text=This method has been successfully tested on PyCharm with Anaconda environments.  ``` > git clone https://github.com/geezacoleman/OpenWeedLocator > cd OpenWeedLocator ```  For the next part, make sure you are in the virtual environment you will be working from.

#Text=If you're unsure about virtual environments, read through \[this PyImageSearch blog\](https://pyimagesearch.com/2017/09/25/configuring-ubuntu-for-deep-learning-with-python/) on configuring an Ubuntu environment for deep learning - just skip to the virtual environment step.
#Text=\[FreeCodeCamp\](https://www.freecodecamp.org/news/how-to-setup-virtual-environments-in-python/) has a great blog describing them too.

#Text=Assuming the virtual environment is working and is activated, run through these next couple of steps:  ``` > pip install -r non\_rpi\_requirements.txt     # this will install all the necessary packages, without including the Raspberry Pi specific ones. ```  It may take a minute or two for those to complete installing.

#Text=But once they are done you are free to run the `owl.py` software.  ``` > python owl.py --show-display ```  From there you can change the command line flags (as described above) or play around with the settings to see how it works.

#Text= # Image Processing
Image processing details and in-field results
So how does OWL actually detect the weeds and trigger the relay control board?

#Text=It all starts by taking in the colour image from the camera using OpenCV and splitting it into its component channels: Red (R), Green (G) and Blue (B) (RGB) or loading and converting into the hue, saturation and value (HSV) colourspace.

#Text=Following that, computer vision algorithms such as Excess Green `ExG = 2 \* G - R - B` or thresholding type approaches on the HSV colourspace can be used to differentiate green locations from the background.   !

#Text=\[image\](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/51358498/152990324-d315672c-fb4b-42d2-b4df-363f702c473d.png)  Once the green locations are identified and a binary (purely black/white) mask generated, a contouring process is run to outline each detection.
#Text=If the detection pixel area is greater than the minimum area set in `minArea=10`, the central pixel coordinates of that area are related to an activation zone.
#Text=That zone is connected to a specific GPIO pin on the Raspberry Pi, itself connected to a specific channel on the relay (one of IN1-4).
#Text=When the GPIO pin is driven high ( activated) the relay switches and connects the solenoid for example to 12V and activates the solenoid.
#Text=It's all summarised below.  !

#Text=\[OWL - workflow\](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/51358498/152990264-ddce7eb4-0e2e-4f98-ac77-bc2e535c5c54.png)  ## Results  The performance of each algorithm on 7 different day/night fields is outlined below.
#Text=The boxplot shows the range, interquartile range and median performance for each algorithm.

#Text=Whilst there were no significant differences (P > 0.05) for the recall (how many weeds were detected of all weeds present) and precision (how many detections were actually weeds), trends indicated the ExHSV algorithm was less sensitive (fewer false detections) and more precise, but did miss more smaller/discoloured weeds compared to ExG.  !

#Text=\[results boxplot\](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/51358498/152990178-a53256c0-cfda-46d3-83c8-3ae018b4a40e.png)  The image below gives a better indication of the types of weeds that were detected/missed by the ExHSV algorithm.
#Text=Large, green weeds were consistently found, but small discoloured or grasses with thin leaves that blurred into the background were missed.
#Text=Faster shutter speed would help improve this performance.  !

#Text= # Updating OWL
Updating OWL software
We and others will be continually contributing to and improving OWL as we become aware of issues or opportunities to increase detection performance.
#Text=Once you have a functioning setup the process to update is simple with a single bash script.
#Text=First, you'll either need to connect a screen, keyboard and mouse to the OWL unit or do this via SSH.
#Text=>⚠️\*\*IMPORTANT\*\*⚠️ Before continuing make sure you are NOT in the `owl` directory: e.g.
#Text=`(owl) owl@raspberrypi:~.

#Text=You're good to go with the latest software.
#Text=If you have multiple units running, the most efficient method is to update one and then copy the SD card disk image to every other unit.
#Text=Follow the instructions presented here, to use software already installed on the Pi.  ## Version History  All versions of OWL can be found here.
